outline:

These classes require pre-registration. Send email to pygotham at thepeoplesconference dot com to register.

outline:
How the operating system handles processes and threads.
What is a thread versus a process.
Blocking versus non-blocking IO.
How these elements operate under the hood and how they affect performance.
What you can do improve performance.
What other languages are doing.
title: A Practical Guide to Non-blocking IO, Coroutines, and Concurrency
desc: From the OS on up how coroutines and threads affect the performance of your Python programs and who to deal with them.

outline:
- MongoDB Schema Design
- Migrating from RDBMS Schemas
- Use cases
title: MongoDB Schema Design
desc: One of the challenges that comes with moving to MongoDB is figuring how to best model your data. While most developers have internalized the rules of thumb for designing schemas for RDBMSs, these rules don't always apply to MongoDB. The simple fact that documents can represent rich, schema-free data structures means that we have a lot of viable alternatives to the standard, normalized, relational model. Not only that, MongoDB has several unique features, such as atomic updates and indexed array keys, that greatly influence the kinds of schemas that make sense. Understandably, this begets good questions: Are foreign keys permissible, or is it better to represent one-to-many relations withing a single document? Are join tables necessary, or is there another technique for building out many-to-many relationships? What level of denormalization is appropriate? How do my data modeling decisions affect the efficiency of updates and queries? In this session, we'll answer these questions and more, provide a number of data modeling rules of thumb, and discuss the tradeoffs of various data modeling strategies.

outline:
- Intro
- The Challenge of Database Abstraction
- Taming the DBAPI
- Schema Definition
- SQL Expressions
- Class Instrumentation and Mapping
- Query and Loading Behavior
- Session / Identity Map
- Unit of Work
title: SQLAlchemy, an Architectural Retrospective
desc:
In this talk I'll walk through some highlights of SQLAlchemy internal design
and methodology, based on the upcoming chapter for the "Architecture of Open
Source Applications" book. We'll have a little bit of SQLAlchemy philosophy,
an overview of the Core, and then a 500-ft view of how the ORM goes about
things, with plenty of cool looking diagrams.

outline: Love Django - Hate Schema Migrations ... learn how you can leave JOINs behind and fall in love with MongoDB
title: Evolution without Migrations: Agile Data with MongoDB and Django
desc: Love Django, but hate schema migrations? Need to scale to more than a   few gigabytes of data? Tired of flattening your data, only to have  your code rebuild the hierarchy? This talk will show you how you can leave JOINs behind and embrace MongoDB for your next Django project. MongoDB's hierarchical document-oriented design makes it a natural fit for web development, and when coupled with Python's easy-going nature, using MongoDB with Django is a breeze. In this talk, learn about MongoDB, the most popular NoSQL database; MongoEngine and friends, the Djangonic MongoDB adapter; and watch as we build a highly-scalable online game before your very eyes.

title: Art, Cultural Concern, and Computer Code
desc: I will show some of my art+tech projects followed by an audience participation segment.

outline:
Architecture
  - Web serving (Nginx/cherrypy/bottle/flask)
  - Email processing (postfix)
  - Data storage (MongoDB)
title: Behind the Scenes at Fiesta
desc: This talk will look inside the technology and architecture used at Fiesta (https://fiesta.cc), with a focus on the deployment of Python web apps, processing email, and using MongoDB in practice. The goal is to provide generic insights about the tools we've chosen, rather than information specific to our business.

outline:
1. Tmux
- Overview
-- What is it?
-- Differences from gnu screen
-- Use cases 
- Code
-- Make a customized profile
-- Set as a bash shell - mix python with shell scripts
-- Create a few working scenarios 

2. IPython
- Overview:
-- What is it?
-- Use Cases
--- Integrating with bash/shell scripting
--- Pylab & Scientific computing
--- Parallel Computing
- Code
-- Learn some basic commands, 
-- Setup aliases & macros
-- ???
title: Tmux + IPython = Awesome
desc:
This is a two part class aimed at expanding a developer's toolset with both tmux and IPython.  In the first half, we will learn about tmux.  I will first explain its client-server model and general architecture, compare it to GNU screen, and show some use cases.  Then, we will start using it, create a customized profile, and solve a simple distributed computing problem with tmux.  In the second half of this class, we will start using IPython.  I will first explain what it is and review different use cases.  Then, we will start using some basic commands, customize our profile and aliases, integrate python and shell scripting into the same code, and, time permitting, see some of the interactive scientific computing and interactive distributed computing possibilities.

If you have one, bring a laptop with tmux and IPython already installed.

outline: I'll give a demonstration of Plover using both my proprietary steno machine and a qwerty keyboard with n-key rollover. I'll talk about various uses for steno, including accessibility, wearable computing, and efficient text entry of everything from code to fiction. Then I'll let people try out the software and ask questions. The talk will be captioned by a colleague of mine (using proprietary steno software), so I'll need a projector for her captions. (Or I can also bring my own, if you don't want to rent one.) If possible, it might be nice to have another projector for my computer as well, but if not I can just make the text on my laptop really huge.
title: Plover: Thought to Text at 240 WPM
desc: Realtime stenography lets you type as quickly as you can speak, but until now it's required ridiculously expensive hardware and software. Plover is the world's first open source steno software and works with a $45 keyboard.

outline: MongoDB supports asynchronous replication of data between servers for failover and redundancy. In this session, we'll introduce the different modes the replication, including master-slave and replica sets, and we'll describe how to achieve better durability by adjusting the write concern. We'll also discuss backups and provide some tips on scaling with replication alone.
title: MongoDB Replication in Detail
desc: MongoDB supports asynchronous replication of data between servers for failover and redundancy. In this session, we'll introduce the different modes the replication, including master-slave and replica sets, and we'll describe how to achieve better durability by adjusting the write concern. We'll also discuss backups and provide some tips on scaling with replication alone.

outline: The purpose of this talk is to share the experiences of current PyStar event organizers and to brainstorm on how to improve the distributed event teaching/learning module that PyStar is working to create.
title: Boosting the numbers: Python for Women and Doing Distributed Organizing of Workshops
desc: The PyStar program is a workshop designed to teach all women (including trans women) and their friends who are looking to learn how to program in a friendly non-alpha-geek environment. The material on the http://pystar.org/ site was originally developed by the Boston Python Workshop which was held March 4/5, 2011. Currently PyStar events use a mix of badges from the PyStar site and their own curriculum. As this project continues hopefully this site will be a hub of learning materials geared at all levels of Python learners, with a focus on teaching people in a safe and supportive manner.

title: Monitoring MongoDB
desc: Mongo Monitoring System

outline:
- Steps for determining which design will best represent your data
- De-mystifying the creative cloud: this is a linear encoding process!
- Tips for implementing a design with Python
title: Intro to Data Visualization
desc: Have lots of data? Want to turn it into pictures to help you better understand it or explain it to others? This session will address best practices for encoding information through design, and will look at a few ways of doing this in Python.

outline: This session is a deep dive into the implementation of sharding within MongoDB. We'll review the MongoDB's sharding architecture, which blends ideas from RDBMSes, key/value stores, and large distributed systems like BigTable. We'll then take a look under the hood to show how queries work across a sharded set up, and how data is balanced and migrated.
title: Sharding and Scaling with MongoDB
desc: This session is a deep dive into the implementation of sharding within MongoDB. We'll review the MongoDB's sharding architecture, which blends ideas from RDBMSes, key/value stores, and large distributed systems like BigTable. We'll then take a look under the hood to show how queries work across a sharded set up, and how data is balanced and migrated.

outline:
A talk about publishing in the Python market, and how to build up to
that. I will talk about how to identify a real need in the community, how to
contribute to the knowledge base in the community via documentation/blogging and the ways that
publishing has evolved over the past decade.
